importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The ongoing period of extreme weather events in 2025, including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US, underscores the urgency of improving global early-warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Nearly half of all countries lack effective early-warning systems for extreme weather events, putting millions—especially in developing nations—vulnerable to life-threatening hazards.

The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) reports that disaster-related deaths are six times higher in countries without early-warning systems, and 90% of such deaths have occurred in developing countries over the past 50 years.
Weather, water, and climate-related hazards have killed over 2 million people globally in the past 50 years.

While there has been progress—such as a rise in countries with multi-hazard early warning systems from 52 to 108—the assessment of 62 countries shows that half have only basic capacity and 16% have less than basic capacity.
The situation is most severe in fragile, conflict-affected, and violence-prone regions.
Progress is being made in Africa, with more countries now operating functional websites and issuing standardized alerts.
Early warning systems enable early action, and the WMO's goal is not just to issue warnings, but to empower communities to respond effectively.
The collapse of a Swiss glacier in May 2025, which led to the evacuation of Blatten, demonstrates the effectiveness of real-time monitoring and early warning in preventing loss of life.
Permafrost melt and increasing glacier instability due to climate change are expected to lead to more glacier collapses and rockfalls, reinforcing the need for global monitoring and early warnings.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has called for urgent improvements to global early-warning systems for extreme weather events, noting that nearly half of all countries lack adequate monitoring and forecasting capacity. This gap has led to a dramatic rise in disaster-related deaths—particularly in developing nations, where 90% of such deaths have occurred over the past 50 years. Despite progress in early-warning systems, with 108 countries now using some form of multi-hazard alerts (up from 52), assessments reveal that half of 62 surveyed countries have only basic systems and 16% have less. The situation is most dire in fragile or conflict-affected regions. The article highlights recent extreme weather events in 2025—including floods in Pakistan, Nigeria, and South Korea, and wildfires in southern Europe and the US—as evidence of the growing global threat. It also emphasizes a real-world success: the evacuation of Switzerland’s Blatten village in May 2025 due to a monitored glacier collapse, underscoring the life-saving potential of early warnings. Experts warn that permafrost melt will increase instability, making robust early-warning systems not just beneficial, but essential for global safety.
title: UN pushes for worldwide disaster alerts as extreme weather 'spirals'
